thread.title: Former soldier joined MP Tobias Ellwood's desperate attempt to save PC's life in terror attack
thread.title_full: Former soldier joined MP Tobias Ellwood's desperate attempt to save PC's life in terror attack

author: Sean Morrison
title: Former soldier joined MP Tobias Ellwood's desperate attempt to save PC's life in terror attack
text:
MP James Cleverly pays emotional tribute to PC Keith Palmer 
A former Army soldier has described his desperate attempt to revive a police officer who was stabbed to death in a terror attack that left four people dead. 
Courageous unarmed officer Keith Palmer was protecting Parliament on Wednesday when he was fatally knifed by an attacker outside Parliament. 
Tony Davis, a coach for the British Lionhearts boxing team, said he did his best to assist PC Palmer by applying pressure to the officer‚Äôs stab wounds and performing CPR. 
Mr Davis joined the desperate efforts of Conservative MP Tobias Ellwood to try to save the police officer outside the Palace of Westminster on Wednesday afternoon. 
Speaking during an interview on ITV's This Morning, he said: ‚ÄúInitially when he fell to the ground, I tried to have a look at him and put him in the recovery position. Made sure I checked his pulse. He had a weak pulse. Tony Davis: Army solider describes attempts to save PC Keith Palmer (ITV) 
‚ÄúHe was bleeding profusely. He had a head wound, which didn‚Äôt look too bad although it was bleeding. I know a lot of police were screaming ‚Äòhe‚Äôs been stabbed in the head‚Äô. 
‚ÄúBut then he had another wound in his arm, and another one that I believe was probably the fatal one by his rib cage. 
‚ÄúI put my raincoat underneath him and tried to stem the blood as much as possible.‚Äù Killed in terror attack: PC Keith Palmer (Metropolitan Police) 
Mr Davis told hosts Phillip Schofield and Holly Willoughby how he was in London with the British Lions boxing team and was to attend a press event in the House of Commons when the attack happened. 
On Twitter, he wrote: ‚ÄúToday was supposed to be a good day at House of Commons, but it weren't. 
‚ÄúI am so sorry for the policeman I tried to help. RIP K God Bless.‚Äù Today was supposed to be a good day at House of Commons, but it weren't!! I am so sorry for the policeman I tried to help. RIP K God Bless üò¢ ‚Äî Tony Davis (@armyboxcoach) March 22, 2017 
Mr Ellwood also rushed to assist PC Palmer, who died from his injuries, and performed CPR. 
Mr Davis added: "I got up because I went to look at the assailant, but the MP did a tremendous job and I can't really commend the air doctor enough. 
‚ÄúThey were very professional." 
Ms Willoughby commended the man for his bravery, shaking his hand and labelling him a hero. Westminster attack: Key moments caught on camera 
To this, Mr Davis said: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not brave. I‚Äôm not a hero.‚Äù 
Dramatic images emerged of a bloodied Mr Ellwood attempting to save PC Palmer‚Äôs life. 
Photos from the scene showed him crouched down next to the police officer. Bloodied: Tobias Ellwood (PA) 
Mr Ellwood, also a former soldier, lost his brother Jon in the Bali bombing of 2002. 
Witnesses said the MP for Bournemouth East also gave the man mouth-to-mouth until paramedics could arrive to take over and the Air Ambulance landed nearby. 
Mr Ellwood later told the Daily Mail: "I was on the scene and as soon as I realised what was going on I headed towards it. It is a huge tragedy, it really is. 
"I tried to stem the flow of blood and give mouth to mouth while waiting for the medics to arrive but I think he had lost too much blood." 
The attacker, who died along with three others in the attack, mowed down several pedestrians as he drove along Westminster Bridge before stabbing Mr Palmer. 
The unnamed man was born in Britain and had previously been investigated by MI5 for violent extremism, Prime Minister Theresa May revealed on Thursday. 
Mrs May briefed MPs in the Commons on Thursday morning and gave limited details about the man but said security services had not had any warning an attack was imminent. More about:
